Are we people fools or what?
 
 the "F" word is taboo right? Illegal to say it on public tv, inappropriate to say it in this forum, but let's take a look at this unique word.
 
 The F-word is slang to begin with.
 
 If I said "I wan't to have sex tonight", this this is acceptable on tv, FCC is okay with that.
 
 If I said, "I want to get laid tonight", it's acceptable to the FCC
 
 If I said "I want to get ####ed tonight", I would be fined by and censorship from the FCC.
 
 I could say, "that is messed up" that would be okay with FCC
 
 I could say, "that is ####ed up", serious no-no with FCC, would cost me fines and censorship.
 
 
 The F-word is a synonym to all the above, but somehow it gets a bad rap, why?

 I agree. Also it's perfectally fine to say duck, or muck, or buck. But if I say the F sound at the start, for some reason it's a "bad" word. It's funny how most of the words that are banned are related to sex or bodily functions, yet the word sex is fine. Now I think THAT is f***ed up.

Why exactly is it that we have a fear of some words? Many of the so called "dirty" words are really nothing more than wonderfully descriptive words that can be used to amplify points and place emphasis into a conversation. If a word means the same thing as something else (ie "sex" and "f***") why can't we use them interchangeably. Words are not inherently good or bad. It is he context in which they are used, and the person who uses them that give them a good or bad connotation.

Why exactly is it that we have a fear of some words? Many of the so called "dirty" words are really nothing more than wonderfully descriptive words that can be used to amplify points and place emphasis into a conversation. If a word means the same thing as something else (ie "sex" and "f***") why can't we use them interchangeably. Words are not inherently good or bad. It is he context in which they are used, and the person who uses them that give them a good or bad connotation.

 
 Even though that is true, when being used the "no-no" words are usually used in a way that is offensive moreso than other synonyms. For example, people almost never use the word buttocks to call someone else when they are angry. They are more likely to use the word a$$. People think by making the most popular offensive words censored then it will make the offenses decrease, and sometimes it is true. If someone will get fined by calling someone else a dumbf**k then they will be less likely to say anything because using a substitute, such as dummy, just sounds stupid. This isn't the case in most situations, but hey, it isn't that hard to just use another word or make up a new insult. 
 
 And Matthew S., you jump at every chance to try and make the church look bad. It's rather immature. If I did the same thing about gays, then you'd end up looking like a bloody rectal wart on a bovine's backside (See what I mean? New insults are easy.). It's easy to try and make people look bad. Why don't you try intelligent conversation for once?
